tossups.question: A pianist who get her start after she met Chick Corea in this city released the album Time Control with her group the "Sonicboom." Cedar Walton's album Pit Inn is named for a jazz club in this city, which was where an album was recorded that features Sam Rivers' only appearance in the Second Great Quintet; that album's A side contains "If I Were a Bell" and "My Funny Valentine." A female big band leader who was "discovered" in this city is the subject of the documentary Jazz is My Native Language and recorded the album Desert Lady. Following "Miles in Berlin" and "Miles in Paris," Miles Davis recorded a live album in this city. A nu-jazzy producer from this city recorded the album Modal Soul. For 10 points, name this city of birth of Nujabes (NOO-jah-bess), which also inspired the song "Calling" on the soundtrack for The World Ends with You with its Shibuya district.
tossups.answer: Tokyo

tossups.question: This work opens with Hermes narrating his descent from Atlas, through Maia. A character in this play proves her honesty by describing an unfinished weaving of a Gorgon, and an evergreen wreath crafted from Athena’s original olive tree. Xuthus assumes he conceived its title character at a Dionysiac festival. This play contains a section in which a woman sings about Apollo's graphic rape of her. This drama shares its name with a text in which the title figure is chastised for "twisting and turning" like the god Proteus; that text also compares artistic inspiration to a lodestone magnet. Creusa abandoned the title character of, for 10 points, what tragedy by Euripides that shares its name with a Platonic dialogue in which Socrates converses with a rhapsode about the power of poetry?
tossups.answer: Ion

tossups.question: A man referred to as the fourth ruler by this name hired Vikings for six thousand pounds of silver to attack Salomon’s kingdom. However, he was killed when a raiding band of Vikings under their chief Hastein happened upon him after he’d taken off his armor at a stone church in the aftermath of the Battle of Brissarthe. The Count of Hesbaye, and the Count of Wormsgau were part of a line of rulers of this name, and were its second and third heads. A ruler by this name married Béatrice of Vermandois and spent his early life as a loyal servant to his brother, known either as Odo or Eudes. That man became the first king of this name by rebelling against Charles the Simple in 922 CE, and expanding his power base from Austrasia to Neustria. For 10 points, give this common name of Frankish rulers, including a man known as “the Strong” who was the great grandfather of Hugh Capet.
tossups.answer: Robert [the Robertian House or Robertines, or variations like Rutpert or Rodbert or Robertin or Rupert]
tossups.answer_formatted: Robert [the Robertian House or Robertines, or variations like Rutpert or Rodbert or Robertin or Rupert]

tossups.question: The 1973 paper that introduced this algorithm discusses Lewis Carroll's denouncement of an "unfair method" of determining the second-best player of a lawn tennis tournament. This algorithm is only practical for datasets where the number of elements is greater than 4,000,000 since its running time grows on the order of 22n. The simplified recurrence relation for this algorithm is "T of n, is equal to T of n times two tenths plus T of n times seven tenths plus c times n". Manuel Blum, one of the namesakes of the RSA algorithm, Robert Tarjan, R.W. Floyd et al. introduced this algorithm, which begins by partitioning a list into groups of five. Though this algorithm has a linear runtime, randomized quickselect is often used instead since this algorithm's overhead is so high. For 10 points, name this algorithm that, as its name indicates, choose the middle element of a list of approximately "middle elements".
tossups.answer: median of medians algorithm [prompt on medians selection algorithm; prompt on quickselect before quickselect is mentioned.]
tossups.answer_formatted: median of medians algorithm [prompt on medians selection algorithm; prompt on quickselect before quickselect is mentioned.]

tossups.question: A book of "Studies" by Alexander Koyre attacks this philosopher's notion that scientific thought began in the year 1277, when Etienne Tempier suggested that there could be parallel universes. This philosopher translated the works of Jean Buridan as part of a ten-volume project of a history of cosmological doctrines, The System of the World. He argued that "logic was on the side of [Cardinal] Bellarmine and Urban VIII" in a book arguing that Galileo made very few contributions to science, Saving the Phenomena; that book introduced his thesis that the Renaissance was merely a continuation of the intellectualism of the Dark Ages. A footnote in From a Logical Point of View credits this thinker with the idea that empirical theses are always interconnected. Quine attributed an early form of his idea that it is impossible to test a hypothesis in isolation to, for 10 points, what French chemist?
tossups.answer: Pierre Duhem [or Pierre Maurice Marie Duhem]

tossups.question: This character exclaims that “We are in the perpetual process now” of “creation, maturation, cessation” after learning that the local Chinese restaurant has closed. He is angered when he returns to his place of work and hears Chet Baker on the phonograph. This character orders his assistant to read The Birth of Tragedy, and learns that his assistant is a foster child whose mom and dad were murdered by two burglars in Kansas. He hopes to “ruin the appetite of every son of a bitch who eats there,” in describing a project that he ultimately abandons. He is afraid that the title entity will be “swallowed by black”. At the conclusion of the play, this character returns the $35,000 advance received with the help of the architect Philip Johnson, and fires his assistant Ken. Alfred Molina was the first to portray, for 10 points, what real-life artist who appears in John Logan’s play Red?
tossups.answer: Mark Rothko [or Marcus Rothkowitz; accept either underlined name]

tossups.question: A technique in this field known as “ironing” works by leveraging optimal control theory to enforce monotonicity constraints on an allocation function. A result in this field, called the revelation principle, guarantees that certain social choice functions can be implemented in an incentive-compatible manner. A general solution, known as “implementation theory”, to a problem in this discipline focusing on making all equilibria optimal was introduced by Eric Maskin, who practices in this field along with Leonid Hurwicz. In this field, collective decision making constraints are given by Gibbard’s theorem. If two parties have unknown and varying values on an item, there is no efficient way for them to trade due to the Myerson-Satterthwaite theorem of this field. For 10 points, identify this field, which in which an agent tries to construct a pathway to reach a desired outcome, sometimes abbreviated MD.
tossups.answer: mechanism design [or MD before mentioned, prompt on auction theory]
tossups.answer_formatted: mechanism design [or MD before mentioned, prompt on auction theory]

tossups.question: Lars-Erik Larsson’s concerto for this instrument was dedicated to a man who played it in a quartet with Linda Bangs, Bruce Weinberger, and his daughter Carina. An early concerto for this instrument ends with a tarantella-esque fugue. Tim McAllister premiered John Coolidge Adams’s 2013 concerto for this instrument, which is accompanied by a wind ensemble in the best-known concerto by Ingolf Dahl. This instrument plays the opening solo in Darius Milhaud’s The Creation of the World, whose score calls for it in place of a viola. Sigurd Rascher commissioned Alexander Glazunov’s concerto for this instrument, which depicts a troubadour outside “The Old Castle” in Ravel’s orchestration of Pictures at an Exhibition. Its players often double on flute due to similar fingering patterns, and make use of an altissimo register. For 10 points, name this instrument whose alto variety was played by Ornette Coleman.
tossups.answer: alto saxophone

tossups.question: A common material used in one type of these devices consists of TEMA-BF4 immersed in a solvent like acetonitrile or propylene carbonate. A VCO uses a so-called "variable" type of this device to control the output frequency. Many of these devices are connected in a stack in the structure of a Marx generator. Replacing the normal connection between the inverting terminal to the output in an inverting op-amp set-up with one of these devices creates an integrator. Op-amps which include one of these devices in their internal circuitry are termed internally compensated. These devices can be used to smooth out the ripple present in the output of a rectifier. In the hydraulic analogy, these devices correspond to accumulators. For 10 points, name these devices which separate the input and ground in a simple low-pass filter, since their reactance is inversely proportional to frequency.
tossups.answer: capacitor [accept supercapacitors or electric double layer capacitors or EDLCs]

tossups.question: These indigenous people were afraid to go out at night due to the presence of evil maboya spirits who took the form of humans without navels. The goal is to prevent a ball from falling to the ground in batu or batey, a game played by this culture. This group tied planks around the heads of their infants to toughen their skulls, which resulted in cranial elongation. Atabey and Yucahu are the two main gods in their pantheon, which is occupied by divinities called zemis. This people take their name from the cassava plant, which is one of their staples. They lived in straw-roofed adobe huts, and were organized into groups ruled by a cacique, or chief. The Lucayans are a subgroup of this people, who waged war against the Caribs on the Greater Antilles. They are described as “naked as the day was born” in a series of letters by Christopher Columbus. For 10 points, name this pre-Columbian group.
tossups.answer: Taino

tossups.question: This figure is first met by three travelers on the path to a forest, where he introduces himself by giving his entire genealogy. An alternate source claims this character fought Sambarasura so that Queen Kaikeyi could repair her husband’s chariot. A son of that husband fired an arrow into the ground to summon seven rivers upon this figure’s death. The elder brother of this ally of Dasharatha may have inspired the myth of Icarus when that brother flew too close to the sun, burned off his wings, and fell to his presumed death. That brother, Sampati, was attempting to shield this figure, who turned black from the heat. In his best known appearance, this character attempted to save a woman crying out for the birds and beasts of the forest to save her from her abductor; but, like his brother, this figure lost his wings instead. For 10 points, name this vulture who was slain by Ravana during the abduction of Sita.
tossups.answer: Jatayu

tossups.question: The algorithm IsoPlotter identifies regions with consistent values of this quantity, which are called "compositional domains." Giorgio Bernardi’s group used high and low values of this quantity to respectively classify warm and cold blooded organisms. This quantity is uniform across regions called isochores. This quantity is low for organisms in Firmi∙cu∙tes but high for organisms in Actino∙bacteria. In mammals, the decrease in this quantity over evolutionary time can be attributed to spontaneous de∙amination. The annealing temperature of a primer in PCR depends on this quantity, because the melting point of a double-stranded DNA molecule is positively correlated with it. This quantity is high within highly methylated "islands" in the genome. For 10 points, name this value, the proportion of a DNA strand that consists of nitrogenous bases joined by three hydrogen bonds.
tossups.answer: GC content [or GC ratio or CG ratio or CG content or G+C content or C+G content; accept any answer describing the percentage of a genome that is cytosine AND guanine]
tossups.answer_formatted: GC content [or GC ratio or CG ratio or CG content or G+C content or C+G content; accept any answer describing the percentage of a genome that is cytosine AND guanine]
acceptable: any answer describing the percentage of a genome that is cytosine AND guanine

tossups.question: In one of these texts, their author compares the monetary value of the 442 books he owns to the number of cigarettes he smokes in a year. Another of these texts compares the "period atmosphere" of "Raffles, the amateur cracksman" with James Chase's novels featuring "Miss Blandish". Yet a third one of these texts asserts "there is no test of literary merit but survival" and claims like "[King] Lear", "Tolstoy was not humble and not a good judge of character". A three-part one of these works praises the book Max and the White Phagocytes for being written from the perspective of Jonah. These texts include a criticism of Elizabeth Jones and Karl Hulten, who lacked "depth" when they killed a taxi driver for eight pounds. A review of Henry Miller's Tropic of Cancer called "Inside the Whale" is an example of, for 10 points, what nonfiction works, which also include "The Decline of the English Murder?"
tossups.answer: essays by George Orwell [prompt on Orwell non-fiction or books by Orwell]
tossups.answer_formatted: essays by George Orwell [prompt on Orwell non-fiction or books by Orwell]

tossups.question: Paintings depicting this person and Mary Moser can be seen in the top right of a group portrait by Johann Zoffany. A conversation with the Bishop of Milan, Cardinal Pozzobonelli, inspired an allegorical painting once owned by Gianlorenzo Bernini, which depicts a representation of this person between a woman in red holding a scroll of music, and a woman in blue holding an easel and pointing to the distance. This person, who was married to Antonio Zucchi, reflected on her decision to not become a singer in Self-Portrait Hesitating Between Painting and Music. This artist's works include a celebrated portrait of Goethe when he was 38, and a history painting depicting Gaius and Tiberius as children in its lower left. The Royal Academy was partly founded by this artist. Cornelia Presenting Her Children as Her Treasures was made by, for 10 points, what female Swiss neoclassicist?
tossups.answer: Angelica Kauffman [or Maria Anna Angelica Kauffman]

tossups.question: This document was initially approved after a leader breached protocol by reversing the order in which votes were called at the table, taking the vote of David Peterson last to put pressure on his alliance with Harold Pawley. After a meeting called the “Last Supper,” Clyde Wells agreed to sign this document, but put an asterisk next to his name. The election campaign of Frank McKenna gained traction by demanding changes to this document, reviewed by the Charest Commission. The inventor Thomas “Carbide” Wilson, who patented a process for calcium carbide, owned the summer house where this document was created. It was the first to introduce the “distinct society clause,” one of five conditions demanded by Henri Bourassa. Five years later, a similar document named for Charlottetown was voted down. For 10 points, name this 1987 attempt by Brian Mulroney to gain the support of Quebec for the Canadian constitution, a set of accords named for a body of water.
tossups.answer: Meech Lake Accords

tossups.question: A major innovation in the use of this article of clothing was developed by Sam Kantor through his company Tropix Togs in the 1950s. The Oxford English Dictionary claims that the first mention of this article of clothing in print is in F. Scott Fitzgerald’s This Side of Paradise, in which Amory Blaine brings his to college. This article of clothing was first advertised by the Cooper Company, who targeted their ads toward bachelors and noted that it did not require any “safety pins”. This article of clothing evolved from the 19th-century “union suit”. Marlon Brando wearing this article of clothing during performances of A Streetcar Named Desire, and James Dean appearing in one during some scenes of Rebel Without a Cause helped them gain their everyday popularity. For 10 points, name this top article of clothing that is named after the shape of the letter of the alphabet it resembles.
tossups.answer: T-shirt [prompt on shirts]

tossups.question: This author’s friend Joseph Mitchell inherited his library after his death, and was disgusted to learn that he used strips of fried bacon as bookmarks. A memoir of Paris by this writer observes that having enough money on hand “for three days” is the “optimal financial situation” for the “serious apprentice eater”. This man claimed that some of the worst reporting of his time occurred during the coverage of Elizabeth Bentley in his book Of Mink and Red Herring. His later works include profiles of Huey Long’s brother. This author of the memoir Between Meals wrote a piece calling a man nicknamed Hurricane Jackson a “nanimal.” A comparison of Rocky Marciano to the whale Moby Dick appears in this author’s piece “Ahab and Nemesis”, one of his essays about a discipline of “bruising”. For 10 points, name this longtime editor of The New Yorker whose essays on boxing are found in The Sweet Science.
tossups.answer: Abbot Joseph Liebling [or A. J. Liebling]

tossups.question: According to legend, this man got his highest political office after he hitched a ride on a floatboat down the Ohio River with William Barry. In two Supreme Court cases, he was sued by the company of William Stokes and Richard Stockton, when he refused to pay them for services they provided. He served as the business manager for Samuel Morse, and partnered with Ezra Cornell in their magnetic telegraph company. He donated his home and property, known as his namesake “green,” to serve as Gallaudet University for deaf children. Richard Mentor Johnson hired him to edit the Georgetown Minerva after he tutored Henry Clay’s children at Ashland. He’s better known for editing the Argus of Western America, and becoming the leader of a group that also included Duff Green and Francis Blair. For 10 points, name this man who served as Postmaster General in the Kitchen Cabinet of Andrew Jackson.
tossups.answer: Amos Kendall

tossups.question: This character amuses herself with the thought of walking around naked with toothbrushes tucked under her buttocks. A spider nicknamed “Lord Rubbish” fascinates this character and her lover. At one point, she sarcastically suggests that men and women make babies by sniffing each other’s hands. Her son quotes the The Jungle Book's line “We be of one blood, thou and I” to comfort her. At the novel's opening, it is stated that this character died at the "die-able" age of 31. Her brother married Margaret Kochamma when he studied at Oxford. Tragedies that afflict this character include the molestation of her son during a performance of The Sound of Music, and her niece Sophie Mol drowning in the Meenachal River. At the end of the novel, her twin children have sex. For 10 points, identify this resident of Aymenem, the mother of Rahel and Estha in a novel by Arundhati Roy.
tossups.answer: Ammu

tossups.question: The Hamiltonian for this system unusually possesses a negative quadratic term when decomposed into its normal modes. The invariance theorem for these devices was proven by Brown and Gabrielse, who established that the sum of the squares of the characteristic frequencies of this device is constant to first order for perturbations from the ideal device. The behavior of a particle interacting with one of these is referred to as the geonium system. The normal modes within these systems are referred to as the axial, magnetron, and modified cyclotron modes, the latter two of which combine to create epicyclic orbits. Motion within these systems is used to calculate m-to-z ratios in Fourier transform ICR mass spectrometry. These devices use a strong axial magnetic field and a quadrupolar electric field to confine particles. CERN stores antimatter using, for 10 points, what type of ion trap, which is not the Paul trap?
tossups.answer: Penning trap [prompt on ion trap before it is read] BONUSES
tossups.answer_formatted: Penning trap BONUSES [prompt on ion trap before it is read]

bonuses.leadin: This theory has recently regained attention with the discovery of a bone carving at the “Vero man” site containing a depiction of a mammoth resembling Franco-Cantabrian drawings. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this hypothesis advanced by Dennis Stanford which postulates that Europeans became the earliest settlers in the Americas by travelling along the edge of pack ice in the North Atlantic during the last glacial maximum.

The Solutrean hypothesis is an alternative to the idea that this culture, connected with the tools of infant boy Anzick-1 and named for a New Mexico city, was the first to settle the Americas via the Bering land bridge.

This archaeological site in Virginia, named for the sand dunes that rise over the Nottoway River, was found to contain pre-Clovis spear tips and thus became a major support for the Solutrean hypothesis.

bonuses.leadin: This movie's protagonist receives two tickets to The Music Man for letting his boss Sheldrake use the title location. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Billy Wilder film. It ends with Fran exclaiming "Shut up and deal!" after Bud Baxter declares his love for her.

The surveillance expert Harry Caul destroys his apartment looking for a listening device at the end of this Francis Ford Coppola film. It contains several scenes in which Harry plays his saxophone to jazz records.
A bizarre piece of music shifts in tone as the camera moves from a shot of an apartment to a shot of a picture of an ocean in this structural movie made by the Canadian filmmaker Michael Snow.

bonuses.leadin: This man always carried his signature “Black Notebook” to keep economic notes, and served as the first secretary-general of the Israeli Labor Party. For 10 points each:
answers: Pinchas Sapir [or Pinhas Koslowski or Pinchas Sapir]
Golda Meir [OR Golda Mabovitch or Golda Meyerson]
Rafi [or, if they insist, Reshimat Poalei Yisrael]
parts: Name this Polish-born man sometimes called the father of the Israeli economy, since he served as Minister of Finance from 1963 to 1974.
Sapir engineered the rise of this politician, who succeeded Levi Eshkol as Israeli Prime Minister after the interim term of Yigal Allon, and authorized Operation Wrath of God.

Sapir chaired the “tripartite negotiating committee” which brought together Mapai, Achdut Haavoda, and this third party to form the united Labor Party. It was originally a breakaway group formed by Ben-Gurion, together with folks like Moshe Dayan and Chaim Herzog, due to disagreements including the Lavon Affair.
answers_formatted: Golda Meir [OR Golda Mabovitch or Golda Meyerson]
Rafi [or or, if they insist, Reshimat Poalei Yisrael]
acceptable: or, if they insist, Reshimat Poalei Yisrael

bonuses.leadin: Developing from a talk given by Alan Prince and Paul Smolensky in 1991, this theory consists of three components, GEN, CON, and EVAL. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this linguistic theory, which reframes language as a form of data, in which GEN generates possible outputs from a given input and CON lists ordered constraints. This theory’s name comes from EVAL.

OT is used in this branch of linguistics, whose generative form derives from the book The Sound Pattern of English. This field, founded by Roman Jakobson, features items consisting of distinctive binary features.

In phonology, the order whereby rule A may allow for the activation of rule B is known as the “feeding order”, while this term refers to the opposite order, whereby the activation of rule A cancels the application of rule B.

bonuses.leadin: This task can be accomplished for different diseases by methods named for Gleason, Ann Arbor, and Dukes. For 10 points each:
answers: cancer staging [or cancer grading; or cancer scoring; accept “tumor” in place of “cancer”]
muscular layer [or muscular coat, muscular fibers, muscularis propria, muscularis externa]
dermis [do not accept or prompt on “epidermis” or other prefixes]
parts: Name this task which can be performed by the TNM classification. It involves ascribing a number, typically 0 to 4, to quantify spread of a certain class of diseases throughout the body.

Colon cancer staging involves looking at whether or not the cancer is behind, within, or beyond this region. This region is innervated by the myenteric plexus and is comprised of inner "circular" and outer "longitudinal" parts.
Levels 2 through 4 of Clark’s level for early staging of a particular cancer looks at the the spread of cancer to the thin "papillary" and thick "reticular" parts of this region.
answers_formatted: cancer staging [or cancer grading; or cancer scoring; accept tumor” in place of “cancer]
muscular layer [or muscular coat, muscular fibers, muscularis propria, muscularis externa]
dermis [do not accept or prompt on "epidermis" or "other prefixes"]
acceptable: muscular coat, muscular fibers, muscularis propria, muscularis externa

bonuses.leadin: This poem proclaims that because we have "foster[ed] quack and weed," we have " marched upon but cannot conquer". For 10 points each:
answers: Edna St. Vincent Millay [prompt on Nancy Boyd]
parts: Name this poem, whose opening "Let us abandon then our gardens and go home / And sit in the sitting-room" is said to be a reference to Eliot's Prufrock. It was written two days before the execution of Sacco and Vanzetti.
This author wrote "Justice Denied in Massachusetts". Her other works include "The Ballad of the Harp-Weaver".

Millay's turn to politics after WWI includes writing and producing this anti-war play. This pastoral, which includes Corydon and Thyrsis as characters, features a "masque of tragedy" overseen by Cothurnus.

bonuses.leadin: The phonographs that are part of this project begin with “Greetings in 55 Languages” and include a selection titled “sounds of the Earth”. For 10 points each:
answers: Voyager [accept either Voyager 1 or 2; accept Voyager Golden Records]
parts: Those phonographs are currently headed away from the Solar System since they are on what spacecraft? The first of these spacecraft did a flyby of Saturn.
The “sounds of the Earth” section includes a track composed by Laurie Spiegel that interprets the Harmonices Mundi of this composer, who may be better known for his contributions to science.
The Japanese entry in the collection of music was by this composer, whose “Crane's Nest” from his A Bell Ringing In The Empty Sky was included. This composer is known playing the bamboo flute.

bonuses.leadin: Originally home to the Ordovices and Cornovii, this Welsh kingdom was ruled by the House of Gwerthynion until the 12<sup>th</sup> century. For 10 points each:
parts: Allegedly ruled by the descendants of Magnus Maximus, this kingdom apexed under Rhodri the Great. Described as a utopia, it was later divided into Fadog and Wen-wyn-wyn after the death of Madog ap Maredudd.

After losing to Aethelfrith of Northumbria at Chester, Powys sent troops to help this great king of Mercia defeat Oswald at the Battle of Maserfield. This Mercian king ruled until 655 CE, when he was killed by Oswy.
The friendship between Powys and Mercia deteriorated, when this this Mercian king ordered the construction of his namesake dyke that ran from “sea to sea”, creating border skirmishes with Powys.

bonuses.leadin: This artwork’s background depicts red mountains behind a lake that has a white sailboat in it. For 10 points each:
answers: Paysage coloré aux oiseaux aquatiques [or Colored Landscape with Aquatic Birds]
parts: Name this proto-cubist painting showing three title birds--including a pink flamingo--around a pond. It was painted by Jean Metzinger.
Jean Metzinger may be better known for co-authoring On Cubism with this other painter. This advocate of “crystal cubism” painted works like The Hunt.

Before Metzinger’s cubist period, he went through a divisionist phase, which is a form of this style with larger brush strokes. This branch of neo-impressionism was used in an 1884 painting depicting a monkey on a leash.
answers_formatted: Paysage coloré aux oiseaux aquatiques [or Colored Landscape with Aquatic Birds]

bonuses.leadin: Name the following things related to the Bhopal disaster. For 10 points each:
parts: Thousands of people died when a tank of toxic methyl isocyanate ruptured due to this situation, in which an exothermic reaction is not adequately supplied with coolant. Because reaction rates increase with temperature and exothermic reactions release heat, the reaction auto-accelerates.
The methyl isocyanate had been produced by reacting methylamine with this compound, which contains two chlorine atoms bonded to a carbonyl and was used as a chemical weapon during World War 1.

To prevent thermal runaway, batch reactors and chemical tanks are usually equipped with these safety features, a shell of tubes surrounding the tank through which refrigerant is routed to absorb the released heat.

bonuses.leadin: Detroit News reporter Scotty Kilpatrick preserved photos of this incident by hiding them under his car seat. For 10 points each:
answers: The International Jew: The World’s Foremost Problem
parts: Name this incident in which security guards under Harry Bennett started beating up Richard Frankensteen and Walter Reuther during a photoshoot at the River Rouge Ford Motor complex.

The NLRB rebuked Henry Ford for the Overpass incident and issued a statement comparing it to the Harlan County Coal War, which broke out earlier in this state. A 1937 flood destroyed this state’s city of Paducah.

This pamphlet was compiled by Henry Ford from the anti-Semitic articles he wrote for his newspaper, The Dearborn Independent. In part due to this work, Ford is the only American mentioned favorably in Mein Kampf.
answers_formatted: The International Jew: The World’s Foremost Problem
acceptable: The International Jew: The World’s Foremost Problem
International Jew: The World’s Foremost Problem

bonuses.leadin: According to the book that introduced this concept, this kind of entity may have an "intellectual", "moral", or "aesthetic" distance from "the reader". For 10 points each:
answers: implied author [do not accept or prompt on “author”]
parts: Give this term introduced in the book The Rhetoric of Fiction. It is a "second self" that manifests to the reader based on the way a text is presented.
The Rhetoric of Fiction was written by this pioneer of the Chicago school of literary criticism. He also co-authored a guide to the academic writing process, The Craft of Research.

Wayne Booth's The Rhetoric of Fiction also introduced this two-word term, which describes characters like Holden Caulfield and Chief Bromden from The Catcher in the Rye and One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest.
answers_formatted: implied author [do not accept or prompt on "author"]

bonuses.leadin: This man lends his name to any function of the variables of a dynamical system that is positive definite and whose total time derivative is negative semidefinite. For 10 points each:
answers: LaSalle’s invariance principle [or LaSalle-Krasovskii principle, accept either underlined part]
parts: Name this Russian mathematician who developed a namesake definition of stability for equilibria of dynamical systems.
Lyapunov also names a critical exponent which describes the rate at which two close trajectories diverge. A positive Lyapunov exponent indicates that a dynamical system has this property.

This theorem improves on Lyapunov’s stability theorem by allowing one to establish asymptotic stability even if the Lyapunov function is only negative semidefinite, as long as its derivative is only zero on the trivial trajectory. Though most commonly named for an American, it was first proven by a Russian.
answers_formatted: LaSalle’s invariance principle [or LaSalle-Krasovskii principle, accept either underlined part]
acceptable: LaSalle-Krasovskii principle, accept either underlined part

bonuses.leadin: This culture, which was first identified by Ralph Linton in "The Study of Man", reveres a man who chopped down a cherry tree, thus revealing the "Spirit of Truth". For 10 points each:
answers: the Nacirema [accept Body Ritual among the Nacirema]
parts: Identify this culture that is the subject of an ethnographic monograph by Horace Miner. They avoid exposure of their "body and its natural functions".
In another hoax, this drug, then called Vitamin B17, was passed off as a cure for cancer. Because it is derived from apricots, ingesting too much of this worthless drug causes cyanide poisoning.

In another hoax, William Boyd created this fictitious "abstract expressionist who destroyed 99% of his work". Boyd took this figure’s surname from a group of British museums, one of whose divisions is its “Modern” branch.

bonuses.leadin: According to Lloyd Gerson, it was the goal of many Renaissance philosophers to synthesize these systems, with "one voice, in symphonia" even though they disagree in some "very important particulars". For 10 points each:
answers: Platonism and Aristotelianism [accept answers in either order; accept answers indicating Platonic philosophy and Aristotelian philosophy]
parts: Name these two philosophical systems: one was "despised" by and caused George of Trebizond to be filled with much hatred, while the other filled Georgie with much joy, inspiring his compendium of logic.

This neo-Platonist was squarely on the side of Plato, since Plato "restored everything to God" -, including "ethics, dialectics, mathematics" and physics, at least according to this philosopher’s book Platonic Theology.
Another philosopher who sided with Plato in the debate was this author of Oration on the Dignity of Man.
answers_formatted: Platonism and Aristotelianism [accept answers in either order; accept answers indicating Platonic philosophy or Aristotelian philosophy]

bonuses.leadin: The center of this region is located about 150 to 250 million light years away from the Earth. For 10 points each:
answers: peculiar velocity [do not accept or prompt on “velocity”]
parts: Identify this region home to a gravitational anomaly. Since it is obscured by the Milky Way’s zone of avoidance, it has been only indirectly detected with the peculiar redshifts of nearby objects.
The gravitational center of this galaxy supercluster is the Great Attractor. The Virgo Supercluster and the Hydra-Centaurus Supercluster is part of this larger group of galaxies.

The Great Attractor causes objects to have a non-zero value for this quantity. The existence of this quantity for several clusters, which is the deviation of an object from the Hubble Flow, led Alexander Kashlinsky to theorize a “dark flow”.
answers_formatted: peculiar velocity [do not accept or prompt on "velocity"]

bonuses.leadin: The Thomas Vaux poem "Dittye … representing the Image of Deathe" from this book is quoted by the gravedigger in the play Hamlet. For 10 points each:
answers: Tottel's Miscellany [prompt on Songs and Sonnets; accept Tottel's Songs and Sonnets]
Sir Francis Palgrave [or Francis Turner Palgrave; accept Palgrave’s Golden Treasury]
parts: Name this book which contains the verse of Henry Howard, the Earl of Surrey, and other poets. It is often said to be the first anthology in the English language.
This author who allegorized Anne Boleyn as a hind in "Whoso List to Hunt" is anthologized in Tottel's Miscellany. He is credited with devising the English sonnet form.
Thomas Wyatt was also anthologized in one of the most-popular Victorian anthologies: a “golden treasury” compiled by, and sometimes named for this man.
answers_formatted: Tottel's Miscellany [prompt on Songs or Sonnets; accept Tottel's Songs or Sonnets]
Sir Francis Palgrave [or Francis Turner Palgrave; accept Palgrave’s Golden Treasury]

bonuses.leadin: An alien discusses the three-brained humans of Earth as he travels on the spaceship Karnak towards his home planet Karatas in this author’s book about a certain figure’s “Tales to His Grandson.” For 10 points:
answers: G.I. Gurdjieff (GURD-jee-eff) [or George Ivanovich Gurdjieff or Georges Ivanovich Gurdjieff]
parts: Name this man who included that book and two others titled Meetings with Remarkable Men and Life is Real Only Then When I Am in his “All and Everything” trilogy.

This system devised by Gurdjieff features the enneagram, which explains all mysteries of the universe like the Philosopher’s Stone. Gurdjieff compiled the lectures of P.D. Ouspenksy into a book named for this system.
Gurdjieff was born in this modern country, whose national church is now headed by Karekin II, and was founded by St. Gregory the Illuminator.
answers_formatted: G.I. Gurdjieff [or George Ivanovich Gurdjieff or Georges Ivanovich Gurdjieff]

bonuses.leadin: This novella follows Nikolai, a Moscow waiter who becomes ill and must return home to his village, only to die and leave his daughter Olga and his wife Sasha destitute. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novella which was first published in the magazine Russian Thought in 1897. Its brutal and unromantic depiction of the title group led Leo Tolstoy to call it a "sin against humanity".
Peasants is a work of "uncompromising realism" by this writer, who also wrote the stories "Ward No. 6" and "The Bet".
In a series of "travel notes" published in Russian Thought, Chekhov described the humiliating treatment of the czar's political prisoners in a prison at this title location.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about music that might make you want to put on a sweater, for 10 points each:
answers: Ralph Vaughan Williams [prompt on partial last name]
parts: This composer drew on his score for the movie Scott of the Antarctic to create his Sinfonia antartica. He quoted the Westminster chimes in his London Symphony.

A huge tank of refrigerated liquid nitrogen was used as a percussion instrument in Kraft, by Magnus Lindberg, a composer from this country. Another composer from this country used recorded birdsong in his Cantus Arcticus.
This spatialist composer placed over a hundred musicians around a concert hall for his Ice Field, which won him the 2002 Pulitzer Prize.
